Award.AwardTitle: Fundamental Modes of Galaxy Formation Through Cosmic Time
Award.AbstractNarration: Galaxies are thought to form primarily through the merging of smaller galaxies and the accretion of cold gas from the intergalactic medium (IGM). The aim of this project is to directly detect the low mass building blocks of present-day galaxies like the Milky Way and the signatures of gas transport from the IGM into gaseous halos and disks. The collaborating team will make use of spectroscopic observations that can provide higher contrast between faint galaxies and the sky background than broad- or narrow-band imaging, and will take advantage of recent increases in instrumental sensitivity and their access to large telescopes. The team will carry out 4 distinct sub-projects: (1) Spectroscopic searches for Lyman-alpha emission from the IGM and high redshift galaxies. The aim is to reveal the spatial extent, kinematics and energetics of gas in the early stages of galaxy formation. (2) Line-profile analysis of bright Lyman-alpha galaxies. The data will be used to constrain the relative importance of infall and outflow in galaxies. (3) High resolution spectroscopy of MgII absorption systems in the spectra of background quasi-stellar objects (QSOs). These data will be used to understand the origin of cool gas clouds in galaxies without current star formation. (4) A deep, two-dimensional Balmer-alpha search of local galaxies in an effort to detect cool halo clouds condensing from the halo onto the disk. These projects are intended to be available as doctoral dissertation projects for graduate students in the Carnegie Institution's pre-doctoral fellowship program. The Principal Investigator will also participate in supervising undergraduate students from the Claremont Colleges in astronomy research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Galaxies can grow in two ways: they  can digest smaller galaxies that have formed earlier, or they can accrete gas from their immediate neighborhood, the so-called intergalactic medium. Past observations have taught us much about the stars that ultimately form from the gas, but little about how the gas gets into the galaxies.

Fortunately, some of the energy that builds up when the smaller galaxies or the gas fall in, is released in the form of radiation, most prominently by the Lyman alpha line emitted by  hydrogen, the most abundant chemical element in the universe. This radiation, at least temporarily, lights up the gas surrounding the galaxies, allowing us to gain a glimpse of the spatial arrangement of the gas and the smaller satellites, and of their  motion towards the main galaxy. The astronomical observations supported by this grant have indeed detected some of these cases, including filamentary streams of gas, and gaseous tails trailing behind smaller objects while falling in.

Galaxies not only accrete matter, they also expell gas that has been enriched by their stars with chemical elements  back into the intergalactic medium. It is not clear how and when this happens, and how far the galactic winds can travel. Our observations have systematically studied these outflows where they arise near their source in the galaxies to constrain the physical properties. In addition we found at least one case where we can directly see light emitted from the chemical elements expelled far away from their parent galaxy.

Finally, galaxies are thought to subject the intergalactic matter  to an intense (ultraviolet) radiation that is capable of heating all the gas and ionizing most of the matter in the universe. However, it is currently unknown how this happens, as normal galaxies are surrounded by gaseous coccoons that completely block the radiation, and there are very few instances where galaxies are actually seen emitting even a tiny amount of it. In the course of this project we have found one case where the ionizing radiation clearly gets out of a galaxy. We know this because the radiation hits a gas cloud far away from the galaxy and makes it shine brightly.

 

The outcome of our research has a broader impact beyond just its scientific value as it will aid other researchers who model the process of galaxy formation with numerical simulations. It provides them with constraints allowing them to weed out models that do not reproduce the observations.

Moreover, the research described here has provided an opportunity to further the education of young astronomers, as it was partly conducted by students, who were trained in using modern astronomical instrumentation and telescopes. Part of the projects have served as material for their theses.
